title: Practical Biosecurity Best Management Practices for Broiler Growers

tasks.task: Discussing biosecurity measures for farms during an avian influenza outbreak.
subtasks: Changing footwear when entering chicken houses.
Using booties or slip-on boots to prevent bringing in contaminants.
Disinfecting equipment and vehicles before entry, such as chicken picker uppers and buckets.
Designating specific tools per house to avoid cross-contamination.
Installing hooks in houses for tool storage to maintain clean entry.
Implementing a personal protective equipment (PPE) program for visitors, including booties, coveralls, and disinfectant wipes.
Educating employees and family members on biosecurity protocols, such as dedicated footwear and washing hands.
Using deterrents like orange vegetable baskets or cones to restrict unauthorized vehicles from entering farm areas.
Enforcing visitor logs and mailboxes for PPE to track access and management.
Installing sign systems to ensure disease awareness and compliance.
Closing doors and maintaining minimum ventilation to prevent wild bird access.
Regularly checking and controlling rodents, beetles, and other potential disease vectors.
Utilizing foot baths with proper sanitation for footwear.
Cleaning litter and maintaining dry pads to prevent pest harborage.
Implementing strict protocols for mortality disposal, such as composting.
Training staff to regularly wash hands and equipment.
Limiting access to the farm for unnecessary personnel and vehicles.
Educating about potential risks associated with activities like waterfowl hunting and exposure to convenience store environments.
Using natural deterrents, such as guard dogs, to discourage waterfowl near the farm.
